function_call.name: get_risks
function_call.arguments: {"risks":[{"Description":"Significant variations in HVAC operation requirements, such as ventilation rates, indicate a research gap.","Impact":"Inconsistent HVAC operation requirements may lead to ineffective prevention of airborne virus transmission in buildings.","Mitigation":"Conduct comprehensive research to establish standardized HVAC operation requirements for effective prevention of airborne virus transmission in buildings.","Technologies":"Data analysis and modeling technologies for evaluating different ventilation rates and their impact on airborne virus transmission.","People":"Building occupants, especially those in poorly ventilated areas, are at risk.","Owner":"Research institutions, public health authorities, and HVAC organizations."},{"Description":"No rules for periodically monitoring indoor air quality in a facility.","Impact":"Lack of monitoring indoor air quality may lead to undetected increases in airborne virus concentration, posing a risk to building occupants.","Mitigation":"Develop and implement guidelines for regular indoor air quality monitoring and establish thresholds for airborne virus concentration.","Technologies":"Indoor air quality monitoring systems, data analytics tools for tracking airborne virus concentration, and sensor technologies.","People":"Building occupants, especially those in poorly monitored areas, are at risk.","Owner":"Facility management teams, public health authorities, and HVAC organizations."},{"Description":"Ventilation alone cannot prevent indoor airborne transmission.","Impact":"Relying solely on ventilation may result in inadequate prevention of indoor airborne virus transmission, potentially leading to infections among building occupants.","Mitigation":"Implement complementary measures such as air filtration, UVGI systems, and ventilation controls to supplement the effectiveness of ventilation in preventing indoor airborne transmission.","Technologies":"Air filtration systems, UVGI (ultraviolet germicidal irradiation) systems, and advanced ventilation control technologies.","People":"Building occupants, especially those in poorly ventilated areas, are at risk.","Owner":"Facility management teams, public health authorities, and HVAC organizations."}]}
